abstract.p: New display technologies have begun to provide more innovative and potentially powerful methods to present information to a viewer. However, many of these techniques struggle to deliver accurate full color. In this paper, we address this dificulty by employing the dichromatic theory of color reflection, which implies that many objects can be rendered accurately using only two primaries. Complex display systems with two primaries can be produced with significantly less work than is required for the traditional three primaries. W e discuss methods f o r selecting objects that can be rendered accurately on two-color displays, and we present our experiments with a two-color display using monochromatic primaries.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The workhorse for scientific visualization display is the color CRT. While this display will remain the primary image output medium for quite some time, current research is bringing other powerful display techniques within reach. One trend is the move from strictly two-dimensional presentation t o three-dimensional presentation; the addition of strong depth and motion cues greatly increases the ability to present information. Consequently, stereoscopic displays [l] and head or boom mounted displays [2] are becoming widespread. In addition, the same motivation has led to other novel display technologies. Two examples that seem particularly promising for visualization are true three-dimensional volume displays In this paper, we discuss the possibility of using only two primary colors for image display rather than the usual three colors. The use of two colors to relieve technical difficulties is not new; it is employed in penetration tube technology [lo] and has been suggested for low cost liquid crystal displays (111. The two-color reconstructions studied by Land [12] have also prompted an appreciable amount of research in perceptual psychology for display applications.

Here, however, we provide a physically based motivation for the use of two colors that stems from the dichromatic theory of color reflection [13] [14]. This theory suggests that, for many surfaces, the reflection of a single spectral power distribution from a surface contains only two color components, independent of the lighting and viewing geometry. Consequently, an object that satisfies this criterion can be rendered accurately on a display with only two primaries. While this condition may be valuable for natural images, it is particularly useful in computer-generated imagery, where surface and light properties can be chosen freely.

We begin in Section 2 with a brief introduction to the aspects of color perception relevant t o display applications, and we continue in Section 3 with a discussion of the dichromatic theory of reflection. In Section 4, we describe image synthesis techniques for accurate color reproduction on two-color displays, and we present a simulation of a two-color display with monochromatic primaries.

div.head: Dichromatic Theory of Reflection
div.p: Understanding color reflection is important for visualization because lighting and shading cues are an integral part of three-dimensional data display. Shading cues are often applied t o volume data but are particularly useful when images contain surfaces. In these cases, each surface is assigned surface reflectance properties and is illuminated by a single light or a set of lights.

The dichromatic theory of color reflection can be employed t o describe this illumination process. It suggests that the reflection of light from a single surface under a single spectral power distribution (one light source or a set of identical light sources) often contains only two color components, independent of the lighting and viewing geometry [13][14]. The two components, diffuse and specular, arise from distinct physical processes that are depicted in Figure 2. The specular component is light that is reflected from the surface interface without significant interaction with the material. Consequently, this component is typically the color of the illuminant. The diffuse component is light that penetrates the material and is scattered below the surface multiple times before exiting. This light is selectively absorbed by colorant particles within the material, thereby taking on its color. The validity of this model has been experimentally demonstrated for many objects [17]; however, certain classes of objects, most notably metals, have different reflection properties.

Often, an isotropic ambient lighting term is included in reflection models, to account for light that is spread diffusely through the environment. In many images, the dominant contributions to the spectral power distribution reaching the viewer come from the initial reflection of the light source from the surfaces in a scene. In this paper, we assume that we can neglect contributions from light that has been multiply reflected in the scene. For synthetic images this assumption is frequently accurate; however, for natural scenes the interreflections may be too large to ignore.

div.p: The computational problem of lighting and shading is very complex and is accompanied by an extensive literature [18]. However, several useful empirical lighting models are common in computer graphics. Most of these models follow the dichromatic theory of color reflection, dividing reflected light into separable diffuse and specular terms.

The planar structure in color space arising from dichromatic reflection is used in the field of machine vision [20]. In this section, we suggest its use in color analysis of synthetic images. As one example, we show that if surfaces in a n image are accurately described with a dichromatic representation, color information in that image can be manipulated while preserving shading information. This ability may prove useful if the full three-dimensional information in a scene is unavailable or is expensive to compute.

div.head: Two-Color Displays
div.p: In this section, we turn our discussion to the application of the dichromatic theory to image synthesis and analysis for two-color displays. If a display system is very complicated, two primaries might be much more readily implemented than three. Or, if a display will show only a single object or a small number of objects (a situation frequently encountered in holography), two colors are often sufficient.

div.p: Using Equation 6, we can express P(X) as a color vector, Z, in terms of color vectors of the two primaries, pi and I%, This color vector lies in a parallelogram in color space defined by the vectors of the primaries. The discussion in Section 3 implies that if one wishes to visualize a single dichromatic surface under a set of identical lights, this display can be sufficient. Both the display and the surface have pixel values that fall on parallelograms in color space; if the parallelogram from the display fully contains that from the surface, the display can accurately reproduce the surface.

In principle, if one is given a surface under a set of identical lights, two primaries can be selected t o reproduce it. However, the more common situation is when one is given the display primaries and must generate images that are accurately rendered. This task consists of two distinct operations, image synthesis and the computation of color-separation images.

Therefore, the choice of primaries constrains the surfaces and lights that can be used in a scene.

The first constraint is placed on the selection of light sources. Any number of light sources can be used in a scene, but all of the light sources must have the same spectral power distribution t o guarantee that the color information coming from any point on a surface is dichromatic.

div.head: Display Simulation
div.p: We implemented the above results in a two-color laser projection system, shown schematically in Figure 4. The system uses an argon ion laser at 488nm and a helium neon laser at 633nm; the power from the lasers is matched with a neutral density filter. The laser beams are expanded and spatially filtered before passing through the separation images, which are combined and projected onto a white screen. The color reproduction on the simulated display is in good agreement with the computed images.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, we have discussed the dichromatic model of surface reflection and have shown how it can be applied t o the creation of images that can be rendered accurately on two-color displays. If a display system is too complex to easily implement three primaries or does not need true full color, two primaries may be sufficient. Also, if the images to be displayed have colors that can be arbitrarily selected, or if only a single object or a single class of objects that obey the dichromatic model are to be rendered, they can in principle be accurately reproduced with just two primaries. Applications where these criteria might hold include holographic stereograms, computer-generated holography, and non-holographic volume display systems. While the use of only two colors for display could not replace true full color, it could be useful for many natural and synthetic images.
